index.title: The Natron Theory
index.intro_text:
Once upon a time there was a desert. And in this desert, where logically nothing
                should
                happen, here humanity made its most important steps in development.
index.natron_title: In the beginning there was ... natron
index.natron_intro:
Natron is a kind of salt which was abundant in the Nile valley (now depleted). People have been hand-picking and
                collecting it in baskets since ancient times.

                Ancient Egyptians used natron for at least ten different purposes:
index.natron_uses_1:
Washing clothes, drying food, medical treatment, mouthwashing, ceramics, textile dyeing,
                        insepticide,
                        conserve papyrus, cosmetic and...
index.glass_text:
Natron was also used to create glass. So called "natron glass", which is still the
                most
                common format of glass we use today.
                In fact, this happened way before the Egyptians even dreamed of having an empire. Between 5000 and 4000
                BC they already created small glass amulets and glass beads*.
index.uveges_title: What is glass, and why is it important?
index.uveges_text:
Natron glass is nothing more than natron, sand and limestone "cooked" together on
                851
                degrees Celsius.
                Which means ​Egyptians were able to melt natron since the beginning of time**.
index.question:
Now tell me straight to my face, are you seriously saying that normal,
                healthy
                ancient men didn't try melting stones with molten natron, but only bothered with sand?
index.answer:
Of course they tried!
And what did they find?
index.domino_title: They found a bunch of dominos that can be knocked over
index.domino_text: Dominos like "granite being so hard that it can't be damaged by any everyday chemical" or how our ancestors transported stone blocks weighing several hundred tons over hundreds of miles.
